title: Data Acquisition
text:
1 Libraries

library(RSQLite)
library(jsonlite)
library(tidyverse)
con <- dbConnect(drv = SQLite(), dbname = 'C:/Users/sedit/Desktop/SadiR/ss23-bdsb-Sadtom98/content/01_journal/02_data_acquisition_files/Chinook_Sqlite.sqlite')
dbListTables(con)

#>  [1] "Album"         "Artist"        "Customer"      "Employee"     
#>  [5] "Genre"         "Invoice"       "InvoiceLine"   "MediaType"    
#>  [9] "Playlist"      "PlaylistTrack" "Track"

tbl(con, "Album")



  


album_tbl <- tbl(con, "Album") %>% collect()
dbDisconnect(con)
con

#> <SQLiteConnection>
#>   DISCONNECTED

library(httr)
library(glue)
resp <- GET("https://swapi.dev/api/people/1/")
resp

#> Response [https://swapi.dev/api/people/1/]
#>   Date: 2023-05-24 02:47
#>   Status: 200
#>   Content-Type: application/json
#>   Size: 647 B



2 Example

url <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies"
# use that URL to scrape the S&P 500 table using rvest
library(rvest)

sp_500 <- url %>%
          # read the HTML from the webpage
          read_html() %>%
          # Get the nodes with the id
          html_nodes(css = "#constituents") %>%
          # html_nodes(xpath = "//*[@id='constituents']"") %>% 
          # Extract the table and turn the list into a tibble
          html_table() %>% 
          .[[1]] %>% 
          as_tibble()

title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.
